item.title: Comissioning a plan of a plan
item.description: a plan of a plan is an unfinished artwork by Lily O’Shea that is based on the structure of a staircase. It is accompanied by a text titled life in a project: a time of no time which explores the relationship between project work and precarity. The research process involved in this work focuses on the pressures surrounding creative pursuit and the issue of affording the time and space to maintain a sustainable art practice.

item.title: Curating a plan of a plan
item.description: Detailed here are the practical elements of curating a plan of a plan. Sensitive information such as budget and contract are included in full in the appendices accompanying the introduction to this portfolio. host/ghost commission budget Lily O’Shea was paid an artist fee for her work. Installation costs were low and the venue cost was split between the three producers occupying St Peter’s. Contract A letter of agreement was issued to Lily O’Shea on 30th March 2022.

item.title: About
item.description: Aoife Hayes is a Cork-based curator from Co. Kerry. Her curatorial practice’s primary research concerns include alternative methodologies of productivity and chronopolitics. Recent curatorial projects include; host/ghost, co-curated with Glenn Dunlea, St Peter’s Cork; CRUSH, Backwater Artists Group. Currently completing a Masters of Arts in Arts Management & Creative Producing at University College Cork. Aoife completed her BA Joint Hons in History of Art & French from University College Cork with honours in 2017.

item.title: a plan of a plan and the curatorial
item.description: Curatorial projects are increasingly understood as ongoing research projects rather than once off events. As such, I wish to outline my intention to carry the framework identified in the process of curating a plan of a plan through to future practice and research. While host/ghost was specific to Cork and the local context of urban neglect and dereliction, the curatorial here encompasses a wider approach to practice rooted in sustainable and interdependent practice.

item.title: Practice
item.description: Crush 21st June – 26th April 2022, First Floor Corridor Backwater Artists Group “Having a ‘crush’ is about texture…My surface gets all uneven, my underneath shows through, things shine up suddenly. It’s like ‘being’ crushed material, but also like wearing it, alternately slithery and itchy” – Elizabeth Freeman Crush is an exhibition of work by four Backwater Artists Group studio members that demonstrates a nuance of textures. The exhibition explores everyday life through the materiality of texture, conveying transactions between objects, people, landscapes and labour over time.

item.title: Rebound Arts Festival
item.description: Rebound Arts Festival is a three-day multidisciplinary festival based in Cork City. As we bounce back, Rebound seeks to enliven and reclaim the spaces we inhabit, inspire participants and connect diverse communities across our city
